awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel electrolyzer architectures to enable electrified chemical manufacturing at industrial scales
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the creation of an economical and climate-friendly method to produce valuable commodity chemicals from inexpensive feedstocks such as chemical waste streams. Chemical manufacturing accounts for 8% of global greenhouse gas emissions: waste produced from manufacturing battery chemicals and recycling Lithium batteries could be converted back into input chemicals. The technology focuses on developing new electrodes that use electricity to produce acid and base from sulfate-containing waste streams. This innovation will stimulate the US manufacturing sector by improving energy efficiency, competitiveness, and environmental sustainability. This technology could eliminate 3 billion tons of greenhouse gas emissions through electrification of chemical manufacturing, while recycling or eliminating the production of a hazardous waste. Moreover, the technology is more economical than current methods, increasing the likelihood of widespread adoption. Replacing outdated manufacturing plants with clean, efficient electrolysis systems would provide high-paying jobs and tax revenue for the region.

Conventional salt electrolysis systems rely on titanium electrodes coated with a precious metal catalyst (e.g., iridium oxide) to enable efficient operation. The metal catalysts used for these coatings are expensive, rare, and fragile. This means that the capital cost of existing salt splitting systems is high, while their operating conditions (e.g., temperature, current density, and operating efficiency) are fairly limited. This innovation will develop gas diffusion electrodes that can help produce acid and base electrolytically from sulfate waste streams at industrial cost parity. The unique microstructure and materials design of the electrodes minimizes the use of precious metal catalysts to lower costs, enhances lifetime for robust operation under corrosive environments, and achieves higher operating temperature (>75 C) and improved current density (5000 A/m2) for lower operating costs. In this project, Design-of-Experiment principles will be used to determine the best combinations of binder, catalyst, and filler/support materials to outperform conventional systems. Optimal chemical and electrochemical properties will be sought for high electrical conductivity, ability to withstand corrosion in highly acidic environments, and minimal oxidative dissolution of catalyst. The durability and efficiency of the new electrodes will be tested first at the lab scale (25 cm2) for 100 hours and then scaled up to 500 cm2 cells for pilot-scale analysis. In all studies, actual sodium sulfate waste obtained from industrial partners will be utilized. The effects of impurities ions in the feed stream on the electrode and membranes will be tracked via spectroscopy and electron microscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Aepnus Technology has successfully developed and tested an advanced electrochemical process for recycling sodium sulfate, a common industrial waste byproduct, into valuable chemicals—caustic soda (sodium hydroxide) and sulfuric acid. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I program, focused on demonstrating the feasibility, efficiency, and scalability of Aepnus’ gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs) for industrial sodium sulfate electrolysis.

Problem and Impact
Sodium sulfate is generated in large quantities by industries such as battery recycling, critical minerals mining, paper and pulp, pigment manufacturing, and textiles. Traditionally, this waste is disposed of in landfills or released into the environment, creating long-term economic and environmental challenges. Current methods for recovering useful chemicals from sodium sulfate are energy-intensive and cost-prohibitive. The Aepnus process provides an economically viable and sustainable solution by converting waste sodium sulfate into two high-demand industrial chemicals—caustic soda and sulfuric acid—while simultaneously reducing costs and environmental impact.

Key Findings and Achievements
Aepnus developed and optimized a novel gas diffusion electrode (GDE), which significantly improves the efficiency of sodium sulfate electrolysis compared to conventional mixed metal oxide (MMO) anodes. This innovation reduces the energy required to split sodium sulfate, making the process more cost-effective and sustainable. Key accomplishments of the project include:

  • Demonstrated High Energy Efficiency: The Aepnus GDE system achieved an average specific energy consumption lower than traditional processes.

  • Improved Stability and Durability: Long-term electrolysis experiments showed consistent performance over +1000 hours of operation, with minimal electrode degradation and high current efficiency.

  • Successful Testing with Industrial Brine: The process was validated using real industrial sodium sulfate waste, proving its scalability and adaptability to commercial waste streams.

  • Economic Viability: A preliminary techno-economic analysis indicated that this process can produce caustic soda at a competitive cost, potentially offering substantial savings for industries currently paying for sodium sulfate disposal.

Broader Impact
This project has significant implications for sustainable manufacturing and the circular economy. By transforming industrial waste into valuable chemicals, the Aepnus process not only reduces landfill use and environmental pollution but also provides industries with a cost-effective alternative for chemical procurement. If implemented at scale, this technology could help industries lower raw material costs, and achieve sustainability goals.

 

Next Steps
Based on the success of this Phase I project, Aepnus is now planning a pilot-scale demonstration to further optimize the technology under real-world operating conditions. Additionally, an FEL 2 engineering study will refine cost projections and system design to accelerate commercialization. Future work will also focus on scaling up the process for continuous operation and extending electrode durability for long-term industrial deployment.

Through this NSF-supported research, Aepnus has taken a critical step toward closing the loop on industrial sodium sulfate waste, providing an innovative, sustainable, and economically attractive solution for chemical recycling.

 


Last Modified: 03/11/2025
Modified by: Bilen Akuzum
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public


Aepnus Technology has successfully developed and tested an advanced electrochemical process for recycling sodium sulfate, a common industrial waste byproduct, into valuable chemicalscaustic soda (sodium hydroxide) and sulfuric acid. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I program, focused on demonstrating the feasibility, efficiency, and scalability of Aepnus gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs) for industrial sodium sulfate electrolysis.


Problem and Impact
Sodium sulfate is generated in large quantities by industries such as battery recycling, critical minerals mining, paper and pulp, pigment manufacturing, and textiles. Traditionally, this waste is disposed of in landfills or released into the environment, creating long-term economic and environmental challenges. Current methods for recovering useful chemicals from sodium sulfate are energy-intensive and cost-prohibitive. The Aepnus process provides an economically viable and sustainable solution by converting waste sodium sulfate into two high-demand industrial chemicalscaustic soda and sulfuric acidwhile simultaneously reducing costs and environmental impact.


Key Findings and Achievements
Aepnus developed and optimized a novel gas diffusion electrode (GDE), which significantly improves the efficiency of sodium sulfate electrolysis compared to conventional mixed metal oxide (MMO) anodes. This innovation reduces the energy required to split sodium sulfate, making the process more cost-effective and sustainable. Key accomplishments of the project include:




Demonstrated High Energy Efficiency: The Aepnus GDE system achieved an average specific energy consumption lower than traditional processes.




Improved Stability and Durability: Long-term electrolysis experiments showed consistent performance over +1000 hours of operation, with minimal electrode degradation and high current efficiency.




Successful Testing with Industrial Brine: The process was validated using real industrial sodium sulfate waste, proving its scalability and adaptability to commercial waste streams.




Economic Viability: A preliminary techno-economic analysis indicated that this process can produce caustic soda at a competitive cost, potentially offering substantial savings for industries currently paying for sodium sulfate disposal.




Broader Impact
This project has significant implications for sustainable manufacturing and the circular economy. By transforming industrial waste into valuable chemicals, the Aepnus process not only reduces landfill use and environmental pollution but also provides industries with a cost-effective alternative for chemical procurement. If implemented at scale, this technology could help industries lower raw material costs, and achieve sustainability goals.





Next Steps
Based on the success of this Phase I project, Aepnus is now planning a pilot-scale demonstration to further optimize the technology under real-world operating conditions. Additionally, an FEL 2 engineering study will refine cost projections and system design to accelerate commercialization. Future work will also focus on scaling up the process for continuous operation and extending electrode durability for long-term industrial deployment.


Through this NSF-supported research, Aepnus has taken a critical step toward closing the loop on industrial sodium sulfate waste, providing an innovative, sustainable, and economically attractive solution for chemical recycling.
